questions.guidance_text: Enter the full legal name of your company as registered with the Registrar of Companies. This name will appear on your insurance policy and all official documents. Ensure it matches exactly with your incorporation certificate.

Provide your registered office address where all insurance-related correspondence will be sent. Include building name/number, street, area, city, state, and pincode. This address will be used for policy delivery and claim communications.
questions.placeholder: e.g., 123, Industrial Area, Phase II, Sector 25, Mumbai, Maharashtra - 400001

questions.guidance_text: Select the date from which you want your insurance coverage to begin. This is typically the day after your current policy expires or immediately if you're purchasing insurance for the first time. Coverage starts at 00:01 hours on this date.

Select the date when you want your insurance coverage to end. Most commercial liability policies are annual (12 months), but you can choose shorter or longer periods. Coverage ends at 23:59 hours on this date.

Enter the address of your main business operations where most of your activities take place. This is where the insurer will assess risk exposure. If different from communication address, provide complete details including landmarks.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Plot 45, MIDC Industrial Estate, Andheri East, Mumbai, Maharashtra - 400093

questions.question_text: Do you have multiple risk locations?
questions.guidance_text: Select 'Yes' if your business operates from multiple locations like factories, warehouses, offices, or retail outlets. Each location where you conduct business activities needs to be declared for comprehensive coverage. Additional locations affect your premium calculation.

If you have multiple locations, upload an Excel or PDF file listing all addresses with location type (manufacturing unit, warehouse, office, etc.). Include complete addresses and nature of operations at each location for accurate risk assessment.

Enter your 15-character GST identification number. This helps verify your business registration and determines applicable taxes on your insurance premium. Format: First 2 digits are state code, next 10 are PAN, followed by entity number and check codes.

Select the category that best describes your primary business activity. This helps insurers understand your operational risks. Manufacturing involves higher product liability, while service businesses face professional liability risks. Choose 'Others' only if your business doesn't fit standard categories.

Describe your business operations in detail including products manufactured or services provided, key processes, target customers, and any unique aspects. This helps underwriters accurately assess your liability exposure and provide appropriate coverage. Be specific about hazardous activities if any.
questions.placeholder: e.g., We manufacture automotive spare parts including brake pads and clutch plates. Our facility operates 24x7 with 150 employees across production, quality control, and administration. We supply to major OEMs and aftermarket dealers across India.

questions.guidance_text: Provide your company website address if available. This helps insurers understand your business scale, operations, and public exposure. Include the complete URL starting with http:// or https://. Leave blank if you don't have a website.

Occurrence Based covers incidents that happen during the policy period regardless of when claims are filed. Claims Made covers only claims filed during the policy period. Occurrence Based offers broader protection but costs more. Most businesses prefer Occurrence Based for comprehensive coverage.

For Claims Made policies only - this is the earliest date from which an incident can be covered. Any incident before this date won't be covered even if the claim is made during the policy period. Typically set as the first date you purchased Claims Made coverage.

If you do both manufacturing and trading, specify the percentage split of your revenue. For example, enter '70:30' if 70% revenue is from manufacturing and 30% from trading. This ratio affects your risk profile and premium calculation.

Select the geographic area where you want liability coverage. If you export products or provide services internationally, choose accordingly. Wider territorial coverage increases premium. USA/Canada coverage is most expensive due to high litigation costs in these countries.

Select which country's courts will have authority over any legal disputes arising from your business operations. This should match or be narrower than your territory of coverage. Higher jurisdiction areas mean higher legal defense costs and premiums.

Enter your company's total revenue for the current financial year in INR. This is your gross income before any deductions. Turnover directly impacts your liability exposure and premium calculation - higher turnover typically means higher premiums.

Upload a detailed list of all products you manufacture or services you provide. Include product specifications, annual production volumes, and any hazardous materials used. This helps assess product liability risks. Format: Excel or PDF with clear categorization.

Enter the total value of assets used in your operations including machinery, equipment, and inventory in INR. This represents your operational capacity and helps insurers understand your business scale. Include only assets directly used in business operations.

Upload your sales data for the past 3 years broken down by product category and geographic region. This helps insurers understand your growth trajectory and risk concentration. Include domestic vs export sales split. Format: Excel with year-wise data.

questions.question_text: Are any other assets insured with us?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if you have any other insurance policies (Fire, Marine, Motor, etc.) with the same insurer. Having multiple policies with one insurer often qualifies you for package discounts and simplified claim processing.
If you have other policies with us, provide policy numbers and types (Fire, Marine, Motor, etc.). This helps in cross-referencing and may qualify you for multi-policy discounts.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Fire Policy: FP/2024/12345, Marine Policy: MP/2024/67890

questions.guidance_text: Enter the name of your current insurance company if you're renewing or switching insurers. This helps in obtaining your claims history and ensuring continuous coverage. Leave blank if purchasing insurance for the first time.
questions.placeholder: e.g., ABC General Insurance Company Ltd

questions.guidance_text: Upload your claims history for the past 3 years including claim dates, amounts, causes, and settlement status. Even if you had no claims, provide a 'Nil Claim' declaration. Good claims history results in better premiums. Include both filed and withdrawn claims.

Mention any additional information relevant for risk assessment such as safety certifications, quality standards (ISO, etc.), risk management practices, or upcoming business changes. This helps underwriters better understand your risk profile and may lead to premium discounts.
questions.placeholder: e.g., ISO 9001:2015 certified, monthly safety audits conducted, automated fire suppression system installed

questions.guidance_text: Check this if you want coverage for liabilities arising from your vendors' or suppliers' operations at your premises. Useful if vendors regularly work at your location. Adds 5-10% to premium but provides comprehensive protection against third-party vendor risks.

Check this if you have technical partnerships or joint ventures and want coverage for liabilities arising from your collaborators' actions. Important for businesses with technology transfer agreements or foreign technical collaborations.

Check this for coverage against sudden and accidental pollution incidents. Essential for manufacturing units handling chemicals or generating industrial waste. Covers cleanup costs and third-party damages from unexpected pollution events, not gradual contamination.

Check this if you want coverage for liabilities during transportation of goods. Covers damages to third parties during loading, unloading, and transit. Important if you handle your own logistics rather than using third-party transporters.

Check this for coverage against natural calamities like earthquakes, floods, storms that cause third-party damages. Standard policies often exclude these 'Acts of God'. Important for businesses in disaster-prone areas.

Check this for coverage against third-party liabilities arising from terrorist activities. Covers bodily injury and property damage to others caused by terrorism at your premises. Recommended for high-profile businesses or those in sensitive locations.

Check this if you handle customer goods for processing, storage, or servicing. Covers damage to third-party property in your custody. Essential for warehouses, service centers, and job-work manufacturers handling client materials.

Check this if you have a canteen or serve food/beverages to employees or visitors. Covers food poisoning and related liabilities. Mandatory for hotels, restaurants, and companies with large cafeterias serving external guests.

Check this if your premises has a swimming pool accessible to employees or guests. Covers drowning, injury, and infection-related liabilities. Essential for hotels, clubs, and corporate campuses with pool facilities.

Check this if you have sports facilities like gym, cricket ground, or courts. Covers injuries during sporting activities. For hazardous sports like rock climbing or martial arts, additional details and premium apply.
If you offer hazardous sports facilities, describe them in detail including safety measures, trained instructors, and equipment standards. This affects premium calculation significantly.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Rock climbing wall with certified instructors, safety harnesses inspected monthly

questions.guidance_text: Check this for immediate medical expense reimbursement for third-party injuries at your premises, regardless of liability determination. Helps maintain goodwill by covering ambulance and first-aid costs. Usually capped at â‚¹25,000-50,000 per incident.

Check this for coverage against non-physical injuries like defamation, false arrest, invasion of privacy, or copyright infringement in advertisements. Important for businesses with significant marketing activities or customer-facing operations.

Provide any other information that might help in accurate risk assessment and premium calculation. Include recent safety improvements, business expansion plans, or specific coverage requirements not covered above. Transparency helps get better coverage terms.
questions.placeholder: Enter any additional relevant information about your business or insurance requirements

questions.guidance_text: By checking this box, you declare that all information provided is true and complete to the best of your knowledge. Any misrepresentation or concealment of facts may result in claim rejection or policy cancellation. This forms the basis of your insurance contract.
